commentBody: TRAVELER'S CHECKS are about as obsolete as WESTERN UNION telegraphs.
meh.  I got to the end...counted the number of rebus boxes...realized I had 5 and not 4...and guessed maybe my "NC" was just a "C".   This puzzle left me feeling apathetic.
why in the world are we calling amie a "new constructor"?????
I can‚Äôt get the app version to solve, no matter how I form the rebus clues. Anyone else having this problem?
A kiwi or ostrich may be a ratite, but a flightless woodpecker is a ratatatite.
Enjoyable enough, but my fastest Sunday ever and I like when it takes me a while on Sundays... a slow coffee over a crossword. Not today!
For some reason it‚Äôs not taking my filled puzzle as a solution despite me doing a 1:1. I‚Äôm on the iPad, would prefer to not lose my streak lol

After getting the 23A x 3D cross, I was disappointed that the other three state pairs did not border each other.

But I did not feel reMorse over it.
Oh, that WESTERN UNION twist caught me by surprise and brought a most satisfying "Oh sweet!"  Best moment of the puzzle for me.
In basketball, traveling is a violation, rather than a foul. But refs rarely call it anyway. There are some hilarious compilations on YouTube showing players taking five or six steps with no call.
Boring.
Clear tell constructor is not a baseball fan: Players are "selected" for the All-Star Game - you can't be inducted into a game. Players are "inducted" into the Hall of Fame.

Oh my goodness I am mad at myself! It took me 30 minutes to find my typo! Just did not catch i had ‚ÄúBONSET‚Äù instead of ‚ÄúBOXSET‚Äù because TENnessee is also a state that spans two time zones! ü§¶üèª‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è 
What a wonderful puzzle, Amie Walker! This was so much fun. I was able to make good time til the double rebuses got me. I knew there was a rebus, it just didn‚Äôt occur to me that it was double, so I could not make it work until I read WordPlay. Even though I knew what the letters had to be. It was still very enjoyable. I love a big puzzle like this that has lots of fun clues and answers.
Y‚Äôall have a wonderful Sunday!!
The shared box on 87 down and 91 across doesn‚Äôt accept any letter from A to Z. Both clue answers to missing a letter.

My Diary of a Crossword Fiend review: https://crosswordfiend.com/2025/11/08/sunday-november-9-2025/#ny As I said in the review, the Universal puzzle on Thursday is also called "Swing States," but it's completely different (no rebuses!). I thought it had a really fun theme. I think you can play that one online here: https://www.gocomics.com/puzzles/universal-crossword

I love a Sunday rebus and this one didn‚Äôt disappoint. A fun solve and a great revealer. 

I sometimes mix-up the A state abbreviations. My first thought was ‚ÄúIs Arkansas considered western??‚Äù, then realized AK is Alaska. Doh!

Clever clue for NBA REF [Traveler‚Äôs check, in brief?].

Nice debut of the common phrases FEW AND FAR BETWEEN and I'M NOT A KID ANYMORE.  

MENTAL NOTE‚Ä¶ I like puzzles by Aime Walker.
For the Taxi Driver quote, after realizing UT needed to be in one square, I wondered if I also had to rebus-ify the "NG" ("you talkiNG to me?"). Kinda sneaky, no?

Generally disliked. Thought the trick wasn‚Äôt worth the squeeze. Knew what the rebus square had to be, but I just didn‚Äôt care.

Non-American though, so your mileage may differ.

Some people have a rhyming friend called GAL PAL - they pass the time playing rhyme games.
Me, I have a POTATO BUD. We compare good storage varieties, discuss leaf hopper control, and exchange recipes.
I am still solving. What is the deal with Square 41? No letter is accepted there?!

‚ÄúSince there are no identifiable theme clues, of course, you‚Äôd need some kind of ESP to get this theme very early in your solve, I think.‚Äù

And

‚ÄúThere are two states in each rebus square, which makes the puzzle‚Äôs title, ‚ÄúSwing States,‚Äù a clever hint (in hindsight, anyway, for me).‚Äù

Both add some very apt commentary for this puzzle from the column‚Äôs write-up.

This was HARD. Way too hard for me, and I‚Äôm afraid to admit that. 

But I do think it was hard for the wrong reasons.

I just don‚Äôt understand rebus puzzles. Fundamentally and personally, I just don‚Äôt like them. I don‚Äôt find them clever or interesting. I think they‚Äôre cheap gimmicks to trick solvers and make them think the constructors are cleverer than they actually are. If you don‚Äôt feel that way, that‚Äôs okay. I don‚Äôt understand them, and I don‚Äôt get along with them. I don‚Äôt know how you‚Äôre supposed to figure them out while you‚Äôre solving. It seems like something that only clicks into focus in the rear view.

Moving on.

I found myself swimming through a lot of this puzzle quite well. I think a lot of the cluing that I managed to get was done well! There was a good mix of attainable answers sprinkled with some really difficult trivia. I think some of the answers felt written by a person of a certain age (TV ROOM anyone?), but I can‚Äôt fault them for that.

I will be avoiding puzzles by this creator in the future, but of course wish them well. 

Have a happy Sunday, and some extra cookies from me! üç™üç™üç™
For 23 across, you've got IMWALKINHERE as the answer to "Iconic line from Robert de Niro in 'Taxi Driver'." Actually the line's from Dustin Hoffman in "Midnight Cowboy."

I am going to make this as clear as I can. I hate this. I am not going to finish it. I want a NYTimes CROSSWORD  puzzle. If I wanted some other kind of puzzle, I would search one out. This is clever and all that, but it's not why I come here. Thank you.

I‚Äôm a sucker for puzzles with postal code rebuses, so naturally, I liked this one.  I spotted the answers needing rebuses with reasonable alacrity, but squandered too much time trying to make sense of the order of the letters so I resorted to the old standby technique of across letters/down letters and voila.  Only after another minute or two of staring did I see the postal code western state connection.   Other than the rebus challenge, nothing else particularly piqued my interest.
Caitlin, you refer in a couple of place to 122 across as revealer. It's 117 across (as in your first reference).

Not a fan today, so sorry. Don‚Äôt get me wrong, I love rebus puzzles, and I very much appreciate two way rebus puzzles‚Äîbut there has to be some rhyme or reason to it, and the title ‚ÄúSwing States‚Äù and the revealer WESTERNUNION just doesn‚Äôt cut it for me, especially for a big Sunday puzzle and only four rebuses. For one thing for a two way rebus, once you get one direction it should give you a hint to the other direction, which isn‚Äôt the case here (unless you are going to run every Western state abbreviation, which I had to at MOMTOBE since I didn‚Äôt remember HBCUs). Maybe, maybe if they were bordering states it could pass, but just because they are all Western states is not enough justification. I didn‚Äôt think the themed entries‚Äîor the majority of the puzzle, for that matter‚Äîwere that sparkling enough either (although I smiled at IMNOTAKIDANYMORE). The editors are usually very stingy about passing two way rebuses, I‚Äôm surprised this one got through. I did love the clue for NBAREF though!

TSOTSI is a really wonderful film. Still one of my favorites. Thanks for an invitation from a South African friend, I got to see a pre-screening, followed by a Q&A with the director, in Boston. I was really impressed with the director‚Äôs perspective and expertise. So fun to have this memory come up 20 years later!

I love rebus puzzles but this one didn't do anything for me because:

1) I got all the rebus squares and entered four letters (state abbreviations) without slashes. When I didn't get my gold star, I couldn't be bothered to search for typo, so I checked puzzle. One of the rebus squares was marked incorrect but the other three were fine. So a slash wasn't necessary, except once where it was?

2) The reason I couldn't be bothered to search for my typo is because overall the puzzle was just meh. Uninspired clueing throughout. Nothing about it "sparked joy."

Great Sunday puzzle! 'Western Union' was a perfect revealer. I hadn't noticed that I needed a double rebus, and had assumed that there'd some gibberish as a compromise. The revealer was a nice 'aha' moment, then going back to complete each double rebus was the payload.

Special props for the Alaska / Hawaii!!!!! 

More like this please!
An enjoyable puzzle. Kept WAiting for the a-ha moment and was not disappointed. Fantastic effORt, Amie!

Everyone: please please please just save yourself a headache for double rebuses‚Äîjust enter the rebus for one direction and one direction only. Yes the slashes may work but seems like there‚Äôs always glitches and typos that way. Yes it may annoy you because you feel like you didn‚Äôt finish the puzzle, or one direction or another is gibberish, but just keep the other direction in your head and know you completed the puzzle. Trust me I‚Äôve always done it that way and I‚Äôve never ever had a problem. Or at least if you think you‚Äôve solved it but can‚Äôt find your error try it.

To complete this puzzle I had to know that the double rebus squares worked in EACH direction, which was too much of a stretch for me.

Just glad I didn't spend too much time trying to figure it out.

For me this was one of those puzzles that I admire more in the construction than in the solution - like it was probably more fun to make than it was to solve, unfortunately.
I love a rebus, but this puzzle was a swing and a miss.

Very glad I stumbled into the trick within the first few minutes (my confidence in the Taxi Driver quote paired with my certainty that a FAutOTE wasn‚Äôt a thing), because BOY would this one have been a doozy without it. Instead it was fun, and on the scale of Sundays, a relatively painless 28 minutes.
Destroys my streak every time. Never had a rebus that didn‚Äôt. Never accepts it as correct when I enter it. It‚Äôs like when you

AROACE might be the ugliest word I've ever seen. Just because a word is your wordlist, doesn't mean it's a good word. Not to mention ATON and ALOT ??? And why oh why did you use a STATE ABBREVIATION clue for TEX ?!?!? Bit redundant and does not fit the postal code theme you set up. Amie...(and Will)...c'mon. You guys can be better than this. Not challenging, not intriguing...not fun.

Got the music with only the OR and no NM in the ITSONME , NORETURNS cross.  Others just entered 4 letters no slash.  I like the suggestion that only one of the two leading letters on the rebus  solves.

I so much wanted Athol Fugard to be the origin of Tootsie, the Dustin Hoffman / Teri Garr movie.  Held onto that until the end.  Convinced myself it was Tootsi.

Generally terrific fun in this puzzle!  Missed Id, Ca, and Az‚Ä¶ those didn‚Äôt help me force Tootsie in somehow.  Love NBAREF.

Huh, interesting to see all the griping in the comments on this puzzle. Stumbled onto the rebus relatively early; the column name was a broad clue that helped a ton. No trouble entering the rebuses, I was just glad we were given the number of them so I could stop second-guessing myself on every clue. 
Feels like I'm finally developing a sense for some of the different types of wordplay that show up in these puzzles - progress is being made!
Just about 5 minutes longer than my Sunday record, not bad for a rebus puzzle for me!  Very enjoyable, thanks, Amie!

Woulda, coulda, shoulda gotten that theme without help from autocheck. The title more or less gave it away.

Thanks Amie for a challenging and Sunday-worthy puzzle!
I‚Äôm sorry, no, just no.
This was a 18 Down

Wow, that was a bit of fun - but it took me an age! I‚Äôve only been puzzling for a few weeks now so that was my first time ever encountering a rebus, nor did I even know what one was! I thought something must be afoot but also wondered if ‚ÄúYATALKINTOME‚Äù was a cute way of conveying DeNiro‚Äôs accent (not at all helped by me thinking it was an isAgon not an isOgon). I moved on for a while until I hit IMNOTAKIDANYMORE and knew I was being played (and wound up) like a CASSETTETAPE(s). 

A few I wasn‚Äôt a fan of mind you‚Ä¶ cookies belong in a JAR, and I‚Äôd need more than a few of them (certainly not a little snack) if I wanted to NOSH, even with a few SUPS of milk on the side. But with that sort of meal I‚Äôd need to switch to a NOCAL diet if I wanted to be an athlete, or even an NBAREF. 

Curious to see how LOLCAT went down, especially so close to YADAYADA, UHNO and maybe even DANO for the non-movie-watchers. 

Anyway, time for this sleepy brit to RETIRE for the night, and even though I lost my streak I‚Äôll do an ERICIDLE and look on the bright side of life!
A rebus? Do it yourself.

The Rebus only worked with a slash. I hate puzzles like this where you have to guess the arbitrary format the app accepts. It is a frustrating waste of time. Either accept all permutations of the Rebus (for example for the first Rebus, UTNV, NVUT, UT/NV or NV/UT) or don‚Äôt do these kinds of puzzles at all.
Ruined my stats....

Not a fan of bidirectional rebus solutions in general‚Äîjust don‚Äôt think they make for a clean solve. Substantively, though, my issue with those four squares is that the states don‚Äôt border each other except for one square. I suppose I‚Äôd tolerate AK / HI, too, but the other two‚Ä¶unnecessarily confusing and dilutive of the theme, IMO.

Was expecting bordering states in the same rebus to go with the 'union' bit but that didn't seem to be the case. And was expecting all Western states for completeness rather than a few random ones. Didn't fully understand how the 'theme' was even a theme.
I just didn‚Äôt have the energy for the double revised.  For the first time in years I just gave up my streak and used the reveal function.
Some of these states are not "swing states" like UT, HI, and AK. But I guess the word "swing" is punny here.

I understood the rebus quickly, but I don‚Äôt really care for it since there is no apparent connection between the two states occupying each square. 

Solving the answer in one direction does absolutely nothing to help you solve the word that intersects through the rebus, because it‚Äôs basically as if the word doesn‚Äôt intersect at all -  every letter used in the rebus square is only part of one answer.

And I would strongly urge, AGAIN, that you simply have the app accept any rebus entry at all as a correct answer for squares with a rebus. Nine times out of ten, the solver only has the square entered ‚Äúwrong‚Äù because they don‚Äôt know what syntax they are expected to use. If they got everything else right and only fudged the rebus syntax, they clearly knew the answer and you should just take it.
Call me shallow, but any puzzle that challenges me and that I can complete is a good puzzle. That includes this one.

MA/NY nos to what to me seemed like a classic Sunday rebus puzzle.  It would have been right at home in the 1990s.  E.g., See 10/31/1999 ‚ÄúTwin States‚Äù Sunday puzzle by Frank Longo (who is responsible for starting the Spelling Bee).  Indeed, the bottom of the puzzle seemed to be a paean to the 1990s, from CASSETTE TAPES to TV ROOM to a 1990s sitcom (ON OUR OWN) to QVC to WESTERN UNION (money orders!) to CONAN O‚ÄôBrien to ‚ÄúACHY Breaky Heart‚Äù to . . . well, perhaps not ARO ACE.

I hold dear the tradition of the Sunday NYT puzzle, which has been a constant throughout my adult life, as close to a religious ritual as I‚Äôve ever had.  Thank you, Amie, for a delightful addition to that tradition.

I don't mind a rebus puzzle.  And I figured out the bidirectional rebus aspect pretty fast.  But a bidirectional rebus just seems like sloppy puzzle-writing.  I can't remember ever being bored by a Sunday puzzle before, and I've been solving for forty years.  Meh, I'm sure some will find it just ducky.
Question: If people hate rebus puzzles so much, why do they tackle them? Can't they just skip them?

Found the rebus right away at 23 across, then the Swing State title helped me understand what was going on with 12 down and 41 across  - was able to go back for 3 down. Ignore the YADA YADA from the anti-rebus crowd (though I‚Äôm sympathetic to tech issues), this was a fun puzzle :-)
No thanks on this one. Nothing much to learn and have to redo the rebus squares to figure out whatever arbitrary format is accepted.

Why would there be "activities" on a cassette tape though?  And why would one need to wind it up when cassette tapes kinda wind themselves?  Of course like all us GenXers I have hand-wound plenty of them after they got tangled (the Bic pens I found most useful for this)...I guess that was an activity?

Ah, i miss cassettes. I loved when people made me mixtapes, they were the best!! I still have them but I don't know why since I have nothing to play them on... but just seeing them brings back happy memories. 

I was devastated when I had to get a new car with only a CD player. Now all my CDs are useless too. I saw a thing on Facebook today about why GenX is so angry all the time, which I'm not, but it was kinda funny -- about having to replace albums with cassettes, then CDs, then mp3s, and now subscriptions. Ha! I pretty much stopped after CDs and just listen to the radio. 

As for the puzzle, I seem to be the minority, but I liked it. I don't think I've met a rebus puzzle that I haven't liked. I like the extra challenge and I love figuring out which squares and so on. Makes me feel so proud when I realize it's a rebus and I can figure out how it works. I love that feeling!! Huzzah!!

I might be too simple to be picky, but even ones that are a bit more meh, I find so much comfort in them. There's always a right answer. It's always possible to figure it out. I don't always succeed, but I know there's a right answer. Would that life were so fair and figure-outabul.  

I especially enjoyed I'MNOTAKIDANYMORE, ENOUGHISENOUGH, YADAYADA (only wish there was room for a third YADA), and YOUTALKINTOME. Also the mention of The amazing goat, SIMONE.  The I'm fine dog meme yesterday, and today we have LOLCAT, who I am far less familiar with than the former.  I thought it was fun!! ‚ò∫Ô∏è

I kinda like rebus puzzles.  I don't find them frustrating, if anything I get rebus puzzles faster because once you figure out the theme a lot of big clues usually fall into place.

I figured out it was a rebus puzzle immediately when YOU TALKIN TO ME didn't fit but it took me solving over half the puzzle before figuring out what the theme of the rebus was.  The HI/AK square gave it away.

The toughest part of me was a part in the center.  I have no idea what an HBCU is, I had "ERATA" for a while instead of ERATO and it took me forever to figure out which state fit in MO_O_E.

Every other answer I didn't know had crossings I did.
As a non-American, I cannot appreciate this crossword‚Ä¶
Rebuses don‚Äôt load on line in both directions. Very frustrating!!!
A little clunky online, better suited for a pen solve. I spent more time than I should figuring out how to get the rebuses to register.

Fun puzzle, though it took me a while!   The puzzle title led me to expect state names or abbreviations somehow.
Since I wasn't getting much traction, I looked for the reveal, which made the trick pretty clear. By luck, the pop trivia  (not my strong suit!!) resolved through the crossings and some guesses.  Then I had 5 fat-finger/ typos to flyspec for the music.

I tried so hard to not need any cheats.  I could tell there were rebuses, and checked the Wordplay, so I could at least be certain of what intersection they were in.  I sweated a bit more and gave into my frustration.  Four cheats!  Fairly enjoyable, all in all!
It's *across*/*down* always. If you enter it that way, and it is actually a double rebus, you'll never be wrong.
Now is as good a time as any to remind everyone that the puzzle title on a Sunday can be very helpful. Today it turned a potential slog into almost half my average Sunday time.

Grr. Finished but had a spelling error I could not spot, so I checked Sam Neill.
Enjoyed after I understood rebus. 
Very clever.

I was struggling from the start but I thought I might be able to solve the puzzle unaided. I did not know the revealer: I got UNION with the help of crosses, but the first word remained a mystery. Not that it mattered much - the way the revealer was worded made it obvious 4 rebuses would be involved, and the puzzle title implied it would be about US state abbreviations.

I got three out of the four rebuses on my own. But that's where my fun ended.

The grid was very naticky for me in places. Despite my best efforts several areas of it were largely empty so I started looking up my unknowns. The cluster of the film quote, geometry term, something related to American sport, and a Hebrew feature was my undoing. I sort of knew the quote - I've never seen "Taxi driver", but that line from it featured in one of Poland's most popular comedies of the 1990s, "Killer", or maybe its sequel. I entered Ya TALKIN TO ME. It looked good enough, as did the resulting ISaGON. The sporting thing was a huge enigma though (the missing letter in DO_, the Hebrew thing, was no help at all) so I looked it up... And spoiled the final rebus square in the process ü´§

Now, maybe the above was my personal experience only, but I really dislike it when a rebus falls on the cross of two entries I perceive as trivia. 

I like rebuses in general, but once I had unwittingly spoiled the solve for myself, I just revealed the rest of the puzzle ü§∑üèΩ.

Also, what's a flippin' HBCUS???
I could not figure it out... until I wrote the letters down on a separate sheet and bang! It hit me. Very cool.
Tedious.

This puzzle was the perfect way, for me, to spend this little span of time patiently waiting for godot.

I liked it a lot, loved the clever conjunctions of states.  (I haven't read Wordplay yet, so I'm probably missing some of the jokes.)

I remain in isolation, but I feel fine and honestly I wouldn't mind staying in this little old man cave until, uh...maybe indefinitely?  

No time here.  I sleep when I'm tired.  Don't when I'm not.  Don't have to worry about staying up too late.   Or about not eating stuff at the right time of day.  If you're hungry for something associated with a time of day, like eggs or alcohol, you don't worry about it.  

You just enjoy your eggs and alcohol.

I hope limbo is kinda like this.
Rebus puzzles often end up with users trying to guess how it needs to be entered. That's a failure of the Times. If they can't sort it out to a consistent input they should not run rebus puzzles.

yeah yeah...i know, i know...YADAYADA...no niggling on weekends because weekends are anything goes! a bacchanal of rubbery inexactitude for the sake of clever cluing! but friends...i humbly submit...utah, hawaii, arkansas, montana, washington, new mexico and oregon have never been swing states. in fact, some are regarded by pundits as reliably safe states as repeatedly demonstrated by their red/blue-voting denizens. therefore, i call political and, therefore, definitional bullpucky on this theme.
Worst puzzle ever.
Knowing what goes in the rebus but having no idea what order or format the puzzle expects is asinine. Standardize or provide instructions.

I hated this puzzle. Can we please have just one gimmick in a puzzle instead of two (that don‚Äôt work together) 

Okay, so you want to do a rebus? But you want to be really clever and add a double rebus? Well make them work. How does New Mexico (NM) and Oregon (OR) fit together in one rebus? They don‚Äôt. Neither do any of the others. This is how you get a sloppy puzzle. A constructor that wanted to create a creative, tricky puzzle without making any sense.

Garbage. Please don‚Äôt use this kind of trash. 

Sincerely,

Everyone.

I paid attention to the puzzle title for a change, and then I figured out there were rebuses, and in both directions, and one set of letters didn't work. So when I ran into the first one at 23A/3D, and that the entry was UT/NV, I knew it was going to be state abbreviations, but it took getting to the revealer to know that they were all going to be western states.

I was a bit tired when I started this one, so I got bogged down and took a break a little over halfway through. The rest cleared out some cobwebs and I managed to finish a bit under my average. 

Nice puzzle, Amie, and thanks!
HBCUS?? Oh America, don‚Äôt ever change. Or actually, on second thoughts, please do. (I‚Äôm amazed that I‚Äôve found out about HBCUs before Donald Trump has, apparently)
Gimmicky. The format and the interface don't support this kind of space usage well at all, and puzzles like this are just dissatisfying.
Feeling a bit stupid, but I can't understand why 93A is BYES.  A little help here?

I didn‚Äôt particularly enjoy it mostly because I thought it might be cleverer than it actually turned out to be l. Mea culpa. 

I did spend a little time pondering whether the states ought to border each other and whether you could form words using the state abbreviations.

Thanks in any case to the constructor and editors.

First time I finished a puzzle without knowing how I did it. I got one state on all four rebuses so the puzzle was done and ‚Äòcorrect‚Äô  but I had no idea how the second state fit in. Very unsatisfying even though I got the little jingle that said I was done. I was kind of left ‚Äòswinging‚Äô
I only got one half of the state in each rebus. But for the answers that included them I did get the correct answer without using the rebus. Anyway, a clever crossword. Thanks

I will always like a puzzle with a rebus element, and if it's different in the across and down entries, I will like it even more.  Thanks for scratching my rebus itch, Amie.  I only wish there were more of them in the grid, but that's asking a lot.

Solved the puzzle but cannot enter any of the correct letters in the rebus squares on the app. Am I doing something wrong here. Trying to finish this on the app is more frustrating than the actual puzzle

Nice Sunday puzzle. Well done to the creator. As a non-American, I spent a bit too much time trying to figure out why the rebus was what is was. Penny dropped with Western Union, but a few too many 'americanisms' for me made me throw in the towel after I had to check hbcus. I'm a 'finish unhelped, or check the puzzle as soon as there is an answer you cannot get' kind of guy.

Grrrrr.

Rebus rules:

Step 1. Fill the Rebus with some letters and punctuation marks that you suspect are part of the answers. 

Step 2. Fill in the rest of the puzzle. 

Step 3.  If you get ‚ÄúKeep trying‚Äù then go back to step 1. 

Disclaimer: Rebus rules may change at any time to accommodate a creative new theme or the judge‚Äôs whims.

I‚Äôll start with three things I liked about this puzzle, because my brain adores riddle-cracking:  

First, realizing it was a rebus puzzle.  There are no indicators, like circles, to give that away, and the puzzle‚Äôs title certainly didn‚Äôt holler ‚ÄúRebus!‚Äù

Second, finding the rebuses.  They are not symmetrical, or only in the longest answers.

Third, seeing that each rebus square has two elements.  A double-element rebus is a layer more difficult than a single element one. And figuring out, thanks to the puzzle‚Äôs title, that the elements were state postal codes.

I‚Äôll continue with what I liked most of all.  

There I was, after figuring out the above, filling boxes in, workman-like. 

Then I uncovered WESTERN UNION.  Hah! ‚Äì Now THAT was a special moment, combining surprise ‚Äì that there was an in-grid revealer at all (Sundays often don't have them), not to mention that I hadn‚Äôt realized that the states were all in the West ‚Äì and delight at its scintillating wordplay.  

For a moment, the air filled with sparks and the puzzle went from being good to being sublime.

You happified my brain‚Äôs workout ethic, plus you surprised, and wonderfully tricked me, Amie.  You got me thinking, ‚ÄúAin‚Äôt Crosslandia grand!‚Äù  Thank you!

Ideally, the online puzzle should have a better rebus-entering interface. Some rebuses are a cluster of letters that work in both directions, and some are like today, where it is a pair. The interface should allow us to choose which kind we are entering, and display the square appropriately, such as a diagonal line with the two answers in the NW/SE corner, or perhaps an alternating display like you see with the completed puzzle. Having four or more letters horizontally makes it extremely difficult to read.

I realize this is a bit a of a programming task, so a much easier way of making our lives better would be to just have the puzzle validator ignore all non-alpha characters in your answer. We should be able to enter : , * / | # - or really anything to separate our pairs. This is also a simple one-line code change and doesn't require any new UI elements, and would work the same for all platforms the puzzle software runs on.

In general, I am blind to themes and revealer hints, and just slog away, solving, filling letters, until I have to ask for a reveal of a letter or word.  I do this because I want to continue the fun dopamine hit when I complete a word, and then a puzzle.

I've been doing crosswords for about 66 years, and yes, I have gotten "cleverer" at them and at many other things.  But I am just a girl, and I do just wanna have fun.  So let me "hate" the rebus if it harshes my vibe.

@Tahira

Our presidential elections are decided not by the popular vote, but by a weird system called the electoral college, in which each state has a proportional amount of "electors" who officially vote for the president.  Voters at the poll actually vote for these electors, who are pledged to the candidates.  Sometimes, the candidate with the most overall votes loses, because the other candidate has more electors.

At this point in our history, most states are reliably Democrat or Republican.  Those that can go either way are called "swing states," and of course, that's where the candidates campaign most.   

But more importantly for this puzzle, you don't need to know any of that.  All you need to know is that the title is a hint to how the puzzle is solved.  "Swing States" tells me that you have to put a different state code in each direction to solve the puzzle.  You also need to be familiar with the state codes, which even many Americans aren't.

@Michelle

It's N(NM/OR)ETURNS.

In the horizontal answer, the NM is used to give ITSO(NM)E, i,e, IT'S ON ME.

In the vertical answer, the OR is used to give N(OR)ETURNS, i.e., NO RETURNS.

This is a "bi-directional rebus" puzzle.

rambling on....

I don't know if there are any developers here, but amongst developers at all levels I know of there is a thing called a Regular Expression.  

I first saw its fangs studying Javascript.  It may have originated even earlier. It permeated a lot of early development I did.

In this case the solution would be to come up with some relaxed syntax, a "regular expression" that would accept all correct rebus entries and deny all the incorrect entries.  One hundred percent acceptance of "right" entries, and one hundred percent disposal of "wrong" entries.

But here's the thing:  If you identify a problem that might be solved with Regular Expressions, then you now have two problems:  the original problem and a new problem of working with Regular Expressions.

No doubt there are high masters of Regular Expressions that would have dried all my tears, but I ne'er found them.

A code that can handle the level of creativity shown by a battalion of cross word solvers would not just be genius, it would be magic.

Maybe AI will prove me wrong.

A FIND operation is a process thst lets you tell your machine to find some string of characters in a piece of text. On Macs, it's COMMAND/F. On PCs, it's CTRL/F. On phones, the three vertical dots or bars at the top conceal a drop-down list AKA menu of stuff your machine can do; this usually includes "Find in page".
Whichever you're using, you'll be presented with a gray bar or empty box in which to type what you're looking for. Hit ENTER or GO and  your machine will highlight every appearance of what you've searched.
Good luck!
